metadata.name: Survival Guide
metadata.disclaimer: This information is general survival guidance and is not a substitute for professional training. Always use your judgment and prioritize safety in real-world situations.

entries.title: Fire Starting (Basics)
entries.summary: Build and light a small, controlled fire for warmth, cooking, and signaling when resources are limited.
steps: Choose a safe fire site on bare soil or rock, away from overhanging branches, dry grass, or tents.
Clear a circle at least 1–2 meters (3–6 feet) wide down to mineral soil; remove leaves, sticks, and duff.
If possible, build a small fire ring or use existing fire rings to contain your fire.
Gather three types of fuel before lighting: tinder (very fine, dry material), kindling (small sticks about pencil thickness), and fuel wood (larger sticks and branches).
Select tinder such as dry grass, shredded bark, wood shavings, cotton pads, or birch bark. Keep it as dry and fluffy as possible.
Build a small fire structure: common options include a teepee (sticks leaning together), log cabin (small square stack), or lean-to (kindling leaning over the tinder).
Place tinder in the center and arrange kindling loosely above it so air can flow; avoid packing it too tightly.
Using your ignition source (matches, lighter, ferro rod, or other), light the tinder at several points, shielding the flame from wind with your body or hands.
Gently blow at the base of the tinder to feed oxygen, being careful not to scatter embers.
As the kindling catches, gradually add slightly larger sticks, allowing each layer to ignite before adding more.
Maintain a small, controlled fire sized for your task rather than a large, wasteful blaze.
Keep extra dry tinder and kindling stored under cover for relighting if needed.
do_not: Do not build a fire under low branches, near dry brush, or inside tents or enclosed shelters.
Do not use flammable liquids like fuel or alcohol unless you fully understand the risk.
Do not leave a fire unattended, even for a short time.
Do not build a fire larger than necessary; large fires are harder to control and require more fuel.
watch_for: Wind changes that could blow embers into dry grass, leaves, or your shelter.
Crackling or rolling logs that may escape the fire ring.
Exhaustion or dehydration while collecting wood; pace yourself, especially in extreme weather.
notes: In wet conditions, look for dry material inside dead standing trees, under overhangs, or inside bark.
Carry at least two reliable ignition methods in your kit, such as a lighter and a ferro rod.
Practice building small, efficient fires before you need the skill in a true emergency.

entries.title: Fire Starting in Wet Conditions
entries.summary: Light a fire when wood and ground are damp or wet.
steps: Look for the driest available location: under dense trees, overhangs, or rock ledges that have blocked some rain.
Create a dry base by laying a platform of dry sticks, bark, or flat rocks to keep your fire off wet ground or snow.
Harvest dry inner wood by splitting dead branches or logs; the core is often drier than the outer surface.
Use a knife or sharp edge to shave dry curls from the inner wood to create feather sticks or fine shavings as tinder and kindling.
Gather extra tinder and kindling—at least two to three times more than you think you need, because some will fail to catch.
If you have fire starters (cotton with petroleum jelly, waxed pads, commercial cubes), prepare them at the center of your fire lay.
Build a compact structure, such as a small teepee or lean-to, with the driest material closest to the flame and wetter material reserved for later.
Light the tinder while shielding it carefully from wind and drizzle with your body, pack, or a held-up jacket.
Feed the early flame with the smallest, driest pieces first, patiently adding slightly larger sticks only after the smaller ones are burning well.
As the fire grows stronger, begin to dry damp sticks by placing them near, but not directly in, the flames before adding them.
do_not: Do not try to ignite large, wet logs directly; they will smother your fire.
Do not skip making a dry base; ground moisture can quickly extinguish a small flame.
Do not use all your best tinder in one attempt if you have multiple chances; reserve some as backup.
watch_for: Steam instead of flame when adding wood, indicating that pieces are still too wet.
Smoke that thickens and darkens, which can mean the fire is being smothered.
Weather changes such as increasing rain or wind that may require additional windbreaks or shelter for the fire.
notes: Carrying a small, dedicated fire kit dramatically improves your odds of success in bad weather.
Practice splitting and feathering wood before an emergency; it is a key wet-weather skill.
Consider building a partial reflector wall to focus heat and protect the fire from wind.

entries.title: Fire Safety and Extinguishing
entries.summary: Use, control, and put out campfires safely to avoid wildfires and injuries.
steps: Before lighting a fire, confirm that conditions and local rules (if known) allow open flame; in high wind or drought, consider going without.
Keep the fire small and contained within a fire ring, rocks, or a dug-out pit whenever possible.
Maintain a clear zone around the fire that is free of dry grass, leaves, and gear.
Keep water, loose soil, or sand nearby at all times to control or extinguish the fire quickly.
Supervise the fire continuously; assign someone responsible for watching it if you must step away briefly.
When you are ready to put the fire out, spread the coals and remaining wood to help them cool.
Pour water on the fire slowly, stirring the ashes and coals while you pour until hissing stops.
If water is scarce, use soil or sand to smother the coals, mixing thoroughly so no hot pockets remain.
Continue adding water or soil and stirring until everything is cool to the touch.
Scatter cold ashes and unused sticks away from vegetation if appropriate, leaving the site as natural as possible.
do_not: Do not leave a fire unattended or go to sleep with a large active fire.
Do not bury hot coals under a thin layer of soil; they can remain hot and start fires later.
Do not build fires in strong winds where embers can travel far.
Do not use stones that may contain moisture from rivers or lakes directly in the fire; they can crack or explode.
watch_for: Embers blowing outside the fire ring, especially during gusts.
Roots or organic material smoldering under the surface after the main fire is out.
Nearby vegetation heating or drying out excessively, raising fire risk.
notes: A well-managed fire is a tool; a poorly managed fire becomes a hazard to you and others.
Cold, wet hands inside the ashes are an effective way to confirm a fire is truly out if you can do so safely.
In very dry conditions, consider using a stove or going without fire entirely.

entries.title: Water Purification (Field Methods)
entries.summary: Collect and purify water from natural sources to reduce the risk of illness.
steps: Identify the best available source: flowing water (streams, springs) is usually safer than stagnant ponds or puddles.
Avoid sources near obvious contamination such as animal carcasses, heavy human traffic, industrial sites, or downstream of camps and livestock.
Collect water from as clear a part of the source as possible, using a container, cup, or improvised scoop.
If water is visibly dirty, let it settle or pour it through cloth to remove large particles before disinfecting.
Boiling method: bring water to a rolling boil for at least 1 minute; at high elevations, boil for at least 3 minutes.
Allow boiled water to cool naturally with a cover over the container to prevent re-contamination.
If you have chemical tablets, follow the instructions exactly, allowing the full contact time before drinking.
If you have a portable filter, use it according to its directions and protect it from freezing.
Improvised filter: layer cloth, sand, charcoal, and small gravel in a container; pour water through repeatedly, then disinfect by boiling or chemicals if possible.
Store treated water in clean containers with lids or covers and remember which containers hold safe water.
do_not: Do not assume clear water is safe; harmful microbes are often invisible.
Do not drink untreated surface water unless you have no other option and are at risk of severe dehydration.
Do not contaminate clean water by dipping dirty hands or containers into it.
Do not skip contact time when using chemicals; rushing reduces effectiveness.
watch_for: Signs of gastrointestinal illness after drinking from new sources.
Sediment or particles remaining after treatment; re-filter and disinfect if possible.
Fuel availability for boiling; plan ahead for multiple days.
notes: Water is usually a higher priority than food; even partial purification is often better than none.
Combining filtration with boiling or chemical treatment provides stronger protection.
Pre-filled, treated bottles in your kit can give you a buffer while you learn the local water sources.

entries.title: Finding Water Sources
entries.summary: Locate potential water sources in different environments using terrain and wildlife clues.
steps: Study the terrain: water tends to collect in low areas such as valleys, ravines, and depressions.
Follow dry stream beds downhill; they may lead to pools or springs, especially at bends or where rock layers force water to the surface.
Look for green, dense vegetation lines in otherwise dry areas; these may indicate underground or surface water nearby.
Observe insect activity such as swarms of mosquitoes or other flying insects at dawn and dusk; they often concentrate near water.
Watch for animal tracks and trails that converge; many game trails lead toward regular water sources.
Listen for the sound of running water, especially at night or in still air when sound travels farther.
In forests, search the base of rock outcrops, tree root systems, or depressions where rainwater collects.
In morning hours, gather dew by dragging clean cloth over grass and then wringing it into a container; repeat as necessary.
In some environments, you can dig at the lowest point of a dry creek bed or near vegetation and wait for water to seep in, then filter and treat it.
do_not: Do not rely on a single clue; confirm water sources with multiple signs if possible.
Do not drink water directly from unknown sources without treatment if you can avoid it.
Do not exhaust yourself searching during the hottest part of the day; use early morning and late afternoon when possible.
watch_for: Animal trails that suddenly become muddy or damp, indicating a nearby water source.
Areas with lush plants or reeds that stand out compared to surrounding terrain.
Signs of contamination like dead animals, strong chemical smells, or discolored water.
notes: Carrying a basic map or having offline maps preloaded greatly improves your chances of finding water.
In very arid regions, water may be scarce; plan ahead and do not travel far without adequate reserves.
Small amounts of water gathered consistently (dew, small seeps) can add up over time.

entries.title: Water Conservation and Rationing
entries.summary: Use available water wisely while minimizing health risks.
steps: Limit unnecessary exertion, especially in heat; rest in shade during the hottest hours to reduce sweat loss.
Travel during cooler times such as early morning or late evening to conserve water.
Wear loose, light-colored clothing and a head covering to reduce direct sun exposure.
Sip water regularly instead of chugging large amounts at once; aim to stay ahead of thirst rather than respond to severe thirst.
If water supplies are very low and resupply is uncertain, reduce activity and focus on finding new water sources rather than continuing long travel.
Use water efficiently for tasks: reuse lightly used water (like from rinsing) for cleaning gear or pre-washing other items when safe.
Monitor urine color and frequency as a rough indicator of hydration; aim for light yellow and regular urination when possible.
Prioritize drinking over washing or cooking when supplies are very limited; staying hydrated is more important in the short term.
do_not: Do not deliberately dehydrate yourself by refusing to drink when water is available.
Do not engage in intense exercise or heavy work during peak heat if you have limited water.
Do not use untreated or dirty water for drinking unless no safer option exists and dehydration risks are severe.
watch_for: Dark, infrequent urine, dizziness, confusion, or rapid heartbeat—all signs of worsening dehydration.
Headache, irritability, and fatigue during heat and exertion.
Signs of heat exhaustion or heat stroke when conserving water in hot environments.
notes: Ration your sweat, not just your water—managing exertion is key to making limited water last.
If you expect to be in dry areas, carry more water than you think you need whenever possible.
Even small sips can help maintain morale and function while you search for new sources.

entries.title: Shelter Building (Basic Debris Shelter)
entries.summary: Construct a simple, insulated shelter using natural materials to stay dry and retain body heat.
steps: Choose a location that is safe from falling branches, rockfall, and flooding; avoid dry stream beds and low spots where water can collect.
Look for natural features to help, such as a downed log, rock outcrop, or thick bushes that can act as a windbreak.
Lay out a ridgepole (a strong main branch or pole) roughly as long as your body plus extra space for gear.
Support one end of the ridgepole on a stump, rock, forked branches, or a low tree branch; the other end rests on the ground.
Lean smaller branches along both sides of the ridgepole to create a framework, leaving a small entry point at one end.
Cover the framework thickly with leaves, grass, evergreen boughs, or other debris, aiming for at least the thickness of your arm.
Add more debris until the roof and sides are well sealed, then place another layer of branches on top to help hold material in place.
Create an insulated bed inside using leaves, needles, or dry grass thick enough to lift your body off the cold ground.
Narrow the interior so it is just large enough for you to lie in; smaller spaces are easier to warm with body heat.
If conditions are very cold and dry, build a small fire outside the entrance and use a reflective barrier to bounce heat toward the shelter, maintaining safe distance and ventilation.
do_not: Do not build directly under dead branches that could fall in wind or snow.
Do not make the shelter excessively large; it will be harder to keep warm.
Do not sleep directly on bare ground; it will quickly drain body heat.
Do not light a fire inside a small debris shelter; smoke and fire risk are severe.
watch_for: Water pooling or running near your shelter during rain.
Shifting or collapsing branches, especially under heavy snow or wind.
Condensation or damp bedding; add more dry debris if available.
notes: Practice building debris shelters in good weather to understand how much material you need.
Carrying a lightweight tarp or emergency blanket greatly reduces time and effort for effective shelter.
In milder weather, you can build a more open version focused on shade and bug protection.

entries.title: Tarp Shelter Configurations
entries.summary: Set up simple tarp shelters for rain, wind, or sun protection.
steps: Choose a site with good drainage and few overhead hazards such as dead branches.
Lay out your tarp and identify anchor points like trees, rocks, or stakes.
For an A-frame shelter, run a ridgeline cord between two trees, then drape the tarp over the line.
Stake or tie down the tarp corners and edges, angling one side lower to block prevailing wind and rain.
For a lean-to, tie one edge of the tarp to a line between trees or directly to a branch, then stake the opposite edge to the ground.
In heavy rain, tilt one side more steeply to encourage water runoff away from your sleeping area.
Use rocks, sticks, or extra cord to tighten sagging sections and prevent water pooling.
Adjust the height of the shelter: higher for ventilation in hot weather, lower and tighter for warmth and wind protection.
do_not: Do not pitch the tarp in a low depression where water may collect.
Do not leave sharp edges or branches rubbing the tarp fabric, which can cause tears.
Do not rely on a perfectly flat pitch in heavy rain; pooled water can stretch or collapse the tarp.
watch_for: Wind direction changes that might require repositioning the low side.
Leaks along seams or attachment points; adjust angles or add tie-outs as needed.
Ground becoming muddy or saturated beneath you, indicating you should shift position.
notes: A small tarp can be configured in many ways; learning a few knots and hitches makes setup faster and more secure.
Combining a tarp roof with natural side walls (brush, logs) improves weather protection.
In hot climates, prioritize shade and airflow rather than fully enclosing the shelter.

entries.title: Hot Climate Shade and Cooling
entries.summary: Create shade and airflow shelters to prevent overheating in hot environments.
steps: Select a site that can provide natural shade at some point during the day, such as near rocks, trees, or cliffs.
Raise a tarp, blanket, or other material so that air can circulate underneath, rather than enclosing all sides.
Orient the shelter to block the highest-intensity sun, usually from above and from the south in many regions.
Keep the roof light-colored or reflective if possible to reduce heat absorption.
If you have extra fabric, create a second layer above the first with a small air gap to increase cooling.
Lie or sit on an insulating layer such as a sleeping pad, vegetation, or clothing to reduce heat from hot ground.
Ventilate the shelter by leaving at least two sides open to allow breezes to pass through.
Plan your activity schedule to rest in the shade during peak heat and move or work during cooler hours.
do_not: Do not build a low, fully enclosed shelter in high heat; it will trap hot air.
Do not sit directly on dark, sun-baked rocks or ground for prolonged periods.
Do not ignore early signs of heat exhaustion while working around camp.
watch_for: Increasing fatigue, headache, or dizziness, especially during midday.
Hot, dry skin and reduced sweating, which may signal heat stroke.
Dehydration markers such as dark urine and strong thirst.
notes: In hot environments, shade can be more life-saving than insulation.
Even minimal shade can significantly lower surface temperatures and subjective heat stress.
Combining shade with adequate water and rest is the best prevention against heat illness.

entries.title: Edible Plants (Safety and Common Examples)
entries.summary: Follow strict safety rules when foraging and learn a few commonly recognized edible plants.
steps: Adopt the rule: if you are not absolutely sure a plant is safe, do not eat it.
Learn and prioritize a few well-known, easy-to-identify plants for your region; depth of knowledge is safer than guessing with many species.
Avoid plants with milky or colored sap, strong bitter or almond-like smell, or fine hair-covered pods and leaves unless you know the species.
Avoid plants growing in polluted areas such as roadsides, industrial sites, or downstream from obvious contamination.

Test only one new plant at a time if you must experiment: touch a small portion to your inner forearm, then lips, then tongue, and finally chew a tiny piece and hold it in your mouth before swallowing a small amount.
Wait several hours after swallowing a small test portion to check for nausea, cramps, dizziness, or other adverse effects before eating more.
Cook plants when possible to reduce some bitter compounds and potential irritants.
Focus on high-yield, safer options like nuts, seeds, and starchy roots of known species rather than many unknown leaves.
Combine wild plants with other food sources such as fish or stored food rather than relying entirely on unknown foraging.
do_not: Do not eat plants solely based on animal behavior; many animals can eat plants that are toxic to humans.
Do not rely on folklore tests like tasting a small bit and waiting a few minutes; many plant toxins act slowly.
Do not consume large quantities of any new plant all at once, even if it seems safe initially.
Do not ignore mild symptoms such as nausea or dizziness after eating a wild plant.
watch_for: Skin reactions like redness, itching, or blisters after contact with plant sap or leaves.
Digestive upset, vomiting, diarrhea, or dizziness after eating wild plants.
Changes in heartbeat, breathing, or vision that may indicate serious poisoning.
notes: Regional field guides and hands-on training offer the best foundation for safe foraging.
Foraging can supplement calories but is rarely a complete food solution in short-term emergencies.
If you feel unwell after eating a plant, stop eating it immediately and focus on hydration and rest.

entries.title: Fishing (Basic Methods)
entries.summary: Use simple fishing techniques to obtain food from lakes, rivers, or streams.
steps: Look for likely fish habitats: deeper pools, undercut banks, submerged logs, weed beds, and areas where currents slow.
If you have a fishing line and hooks, tie strong knots and check the line for damage before use.
Use available bait such as worms, insects, small pieces of fish, or artificial lures if you have them.
Fish during cooler parts of the day (early morning, evening) when many species are more active near the surface.
Cast or drop your bait near cover where fish may hide, being careful to avoid snags.
Be patient and minimize noise and vibration along the bank to avoid spooking fish.
If allowed by your context and local rules (when known), you may set passive lines by anchoring baited hooks to branches or stakes and checking them regularly.
Handle fish carefully; keep them cool and clean until you are ready to prepare them.
Cook fish thoroughly over a fire or heat source until the flesh is opaque and flakes easily.
do_not: Do not fish in obviously contaminated water if you have safer food options.
Do not leave unattended lines where animals or people may be accidentally hooked.
Do not waste bait; retrieve and reuse it when possible if you move locations.
watch_for: Signs of fish activity such as splashes, surface feeding, or visible schooling near shore.
Changes in water level or current that might affect where fish congregate.
Spoilage signs such as bad odor or slimy texture if fish are left unrefrigerated for long.
notes: Even simple handlines can be effective with patience and good placement.
Learning a few reliable knots and bait rigs improves success rates.
Fish provide valuable protein and fats that are often hard to obtain from plants alone.

entries.title: Small Game (General Considerations)
entries.summary: Understand basic principles around obtaining and using small game for food without detailed hunting tactics.
steps: Recognize that capturing small game requires energy and time; weigh potential return against effort and risk.
Look for signs of small animals such as tracks, droppings, burrows, nests, and well-worn trails.
Position any lawful or context-appropriate methods near areas of frequent animal movement, such as along game trails, near water, or at burrow entrances.
Check your setups regularly to avoid unnecessary suffering of animals and to protect meat from spoilage and scavengers.
Once small game is obtained, keep it cool, clean, and shaded until you can prepare it.
Prepare animals away from your sleeping area to avoid attracting predators and scavengers to where you rest.
Cook meat thoroughly, ensuring that no pink or raw areas remain near bones or thicker parts.
Dispose of inedible parts and remains away from camp and water sources, burying if possible to reduce attracting wildlife.
do_not: Do not injure animals and fail to follow up; track and recover them if it is safe and feasible.
Do not prepare animals inside your primary sleeping shelter, which can draw unwanted animals.
Do not eat meat that smells bad, appears spoiled, or has unusual discoloration even after cooking.
watch_for: Predator activity near areas where remains are discarded.
Spoilage signs in meat that has been stored too warm for too long.
Illness symptoms after eating wild game, such as severe stomach pain or persistent vomiting.
notes: Small game can be an important protein source, but safety, legality, and ethics should always be considered when circumstances allow.
In some survival situations, focusing on fish and plant foods may be more efficient than pursuing small mammals or birds.
If you are unfamiliar with processing animals, seek training before you need the skill.

entries.title: Animal Tracks (Identification Basics)
entries.summary: Use tracks and sign to understand animal presence, find resources, and improve safety.
steps: Look for clear tracks in soft ground, mud, sand, or snow; early morning and late afternoon light makes prints easier to see.
Observe the overall shape of the track: note the number of toes, presence or absence of claw marks, and the shape of the main pad or hoof.
Measure or estimate the size of the track, including length, width, and stride distance between prints.
Study the pattern of movement: straight, purposeful lines often indicate predators; wandering or zigzag patterns may suggest grazing animals.
Note any claw marks: canine tracks usually show claws, while feline tracks often do not.
Identify common hoof prints: deer and similar animals leave two-part, heart-shaped prints that point in the direction of travel.
Look for additional sign such as scat, fur on bushes, rubbed bark, broken branches, and disturbed ground near water sources.
Use tracks to infer time since passage: crisp edges and undisturbed details suggest recent travel; weathered or collapsed tracks are older.
Maintain awareness of your surroundings when following tracks, especially if they belong to large predators or lead into thick cover.
do_not: Do not approach large animals or follow predator tracks into confined spaces such as dense brush, caves, or thickets.
Do not rely only on a single print; look for multiple tracks and signs before making conclusions.
Do not ignore wind direction; avoid letting your scent blow directly toward wildlife you may not want to encounter.
watch_for: Fresh predator tracks near your camp or water source, especially in early morning or evening.
Clusters of tracks and sign around game trails or natural funnels, indicating frequent animal use.
Scat containing fur, bones, or strong odor, indicating meat-eating animals.
notes: Tracking is a skill that improves with practice; study prints in safe settings before relying on this skill in an emergency.
Animal trails can lead to water sources, feeding areas, or easier routes through dense terrain, but always weigh the risk of close wildlife encounters.
Even if you do not hunt, understanding tracks helps you avoid conflicts with wildlife and choose safer camp locations.

entries.title: Trail Sign and Navigation Awareness
entries.summary: Use natural signs and simple markers to stay oriented and find your way.
steps: Note prominent landmarks such as mountains, cliffs, large trees, or distinctive rock formations as you travel.
Periodically look back along your route so you recognize the view if you need to return.
Mark your path discreetly with small signs such as carefully placed sticks, stones, or broken branches, avoiding damage to live trees when possible.
Use the position of the sun to maintain a general sense of direction, remembering it rises roughly in the east and sets roughly in the west.
If you have a compass, check your bearing regularly and record directions in a notebook or on a map if available.
In dense vegetation, note transitions between terrain types (forest edge, meadow, ridge line) as reference points.
If you realize you may be lost, stop moving quickly, take stock of landmarks, and consider returning to your last known point.
Use watercourses as navigation aids: traveling downstream often leads toward lower elevations and possibly roads or settlements, but consider terrain hazards first.
do_not: Do not press forward blindly when unsure of your location; this often makes things worse.
Do not mark trails in ways that damage living trees or create unnecessary environmental impact.
Do not rely solely on electronic devices; batteries can fail and signals can be lost.
watch_for: Repeatedly encountering the same landmarks, which may indicate you are moving in circles.
Weather changes such as fog or heavy rain that may reduce visibility and obscure landmarks.
Signs of established trails or old paths that might lead toward human activity.
notes: Simple habits like looking back and noticing landmarks greatly reduce the risk of getting lost.
If you must leave a main trail, note your starting point carefully and limit how far you stray without clear markers.
When in doubt, staying put near a known location can make it easier for rescuers to find you.

entries.title: Wildlife Encounters and Camp Safety
entries.summary: Reduce the risk of dangerous encounters with large animals and protect your camp.
steps: Choose camp locations away from animal trails, water crossings, and obvious feeding areas such as berry patches.
Store food securely, using bear-resistant containers or hanging food from a tree branch when necessary and possible.
Keep sleeping areas separate from cooking and food storage sites.
Dispose of food scraps and waste well away from camp, burying when appropriate and allowed by local practices.
Make your presence known during travel in areas with large predators by talking, clapping, or making moderate noise, especially in dense vegetation or near loud streams.
If you see fresh large-animal sign (fresh scat, strong odor, recent tracks), consider changing your route or moving camp.
Keep pets under control if present; they can trigger unwanted animal encounters if they roam freely.
Know and follow region-specific guidance for wildlife behavior if you have that information in your reference material.
do_not: Do not store food inside your sleeping shelter if large predators are a possibility.
Do not approach young animals or their suspected parents; protective behavior can be aggressive.
Do not run blindly if you encounter large wildlife; sudden movements can trigger chase responses.
watch_for: Frequent animal tracks or scat near your camp, indicating a high-traffic area.
Noises at night such as rummaging around food storage areas or tents.
Birds or scavengers circling or gathering, which may indicate carcasses and potential predator activity.
notes: Preventing encounters is usually easier and safer than reacting once an animal is close.
Clean camps and careful food handling significantly reduce wildlife interest in your location.
If specific regional guidance exists (such as for bears or large cats), follow it as your primary reference.
